awd_titl_txt: Mapping Dark Matter on Large and Small Scales with the Cosmic Microwave Background
awd_abstract_narration:
The light of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) carries a wealth of untapped information including how the Universe was created and the properties of the elusive neutrino particles.  A new generation of CMB experiments are coming online, due in part to a significant investment in experimental infrastructure.  However, there is a critical need to complement this with a significant investment in the analysis of the current and upcoming data.  This award will allow the necessary data analysis to measure the masses of the neutrino particles with Advanced ACTPol (AdvACT) data.  This award will also allow the development of analysis to detect gravitational waves from the early Universe, using Simons Observatory (SO) data,to understand how the Universe was created. The broader impacts of this proposal are that the PI will bring the excitement of cosmological research to young female undergraduates, elementary-school students, and the public. The PI will do this by: 1) mentoring and instructing women undergraduates through the Stony Brook Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Honors program, by 2) being a ``visiting classroom astronomer'' in local elementary schools as part of the Project ASTRO program, and by 3) giving public talks several times per year on a variety of topics such as Dark Matter, Dark Energy, the Early Universe, Gravitational Waves, and the Cosmic Neutrino Background.   

The first research objective of this proposal is to measure how much gravitational lensing has bent the CMB light as this light has travelled to us, using AdvACT data, in order to measure the masses of the neutrino particles. The second research objective is to co-develop the B-mode delensing analysis to detect primordial gravitational waves, as well as oversee all CMB lensing analyses for SO needed for key SO science goals. The proposed research is potentially transformational because it could result in a detection of the sum of the neutrino masses with AdvACT data. In addition, this research could enable a detection of primordial gravitational waves with SO data, shedding critical light on how our Universe began.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Mapping Dark Matter on Large Scales with the Cosmic Microwave Background

 

The light of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) contains a wealth of information including how the Universe was created and the masses of the elusive neutrino particles.  The Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) took data on the CMB in Chile from 2007 to 2022.  During the award period, the PI co-lead the working group within the ACT collaboration that measured how much the path of light from the CMB was bent by intervening matter as this light travelled to us over cosmic time, an effect called 'gravitational lensing'.  The PI and her group developed cutting edge analyses, and for the first time, were able to undo the lensing effect to measure cosmological parameters from the de-lensed CMB.  The lensing working group within ACT also produced the most precisely measured map of dark matter obtained from this CMB lensing signal.  This dark matter map allowed for the tightest constraints on the sum of the neutrino masses to date.  It also served as a powerful test of Einstein’s General Relativity, confirming that structure in the Universe has grown exactly as General Relativity predicted.  

 

This award has enabled over 30 publications, many of them either utilizing ACT lensing data or pushing the forefront of theoretical knowledge about CMB lensing and how to measure it.  This award also provided the PI with the resources to develop a concept for a next-generation Stage-5 CMB facility.   In addition, this award has enabled the research training of three graduate students, one undergraduate student, and one postdoctoral researcher.  

 

As the broader impacts of this proposal, the PI brought the excitement of cosmological research to young female undergraduates, elementary-school students, and the public.  The PI mentored women undergraduate students through the Stony Brook Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Honors program, was a ``visiting classroom astronomer'' in local elementary schools as part of the Project ASTRO program, and gave public talks several times per year on a variety of topics such as Dark Matter, Dark Energy, the Early Universe, Gravitational Waves, and the Cosmic Neutrino Background.  The PI reached hundreds of students and members of the general public through this outreach program.

Images (1 of )
  • Shown is an image of the lensed minus delensed CMB map from the ACT D56 150 data. This image shows the familiar distortions caused by gravitational lensing of the CMB. We also overlay the contours of the reconstructed ACT D56 lensing potential map.
    Han, Sehgal, MacInnis et al, JCAP, (2021)
    Copyrighted
    Neelima Sehgal
    Lensed minus delensed CMB map from the ACT data.
  • ACT DR6 CMB lensing power spectrum shown in red. We find good agreement with the LCDM theoretical predictions based on either the Planck 2018 (shown in black) or ACT DR4 + WMAP CMB power spectra best-fit cosmology.
    Qu et al, ACT collaboration, (2023)
    Copyrighted
    Neelima Sehgal
    ACT DR6 CMB lensing power spectrum.
  • The bolded red measurements are from ACT DR6 lensing data. We find that they agree with expectations from CMB primary fluctuations (green), but are higher than measurements from optical lensing (blue).
    Madhavacheril et al, ACT collaboration, (2023)
    Copyrighted
    Neelima Sehgal
    Measurements of the amplitude of matter fluctuations.
  • The ACT lensing measurements are consistent with the low expansion rate inferred from Planck CMB anisotropies. They are in tension with the Cepheid-calibrated direct inference and are consistent with the TRGB-calibrated direct inference, whose 68% CL bands are shown in orange.
    Madhavacheril et al, ACT collaboration, (2023)
    Copyrighted
    Neelima Sehgal
    Hubble constant measurements with ACT CMB lensing.
  • Probability densities for the sum of neutrino masses from ACT CMB lensing. The vertical lines show the corresponding 95% confidence limits. The minimal sum of masses expected from oscillation experiments in a normal and inverted hierarchy are shown as solid and dotted gray vertical lines.
    Madhavacheril et al, ACT collaboration, (2023)
    Copyrighted
    Neelima Sehgal
    Measurements of the sum of the neutrino masses from ACT CMB lensing.
